QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brereton, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Last Tuesday you told this House that not one minister of a foreign government had raised with you the scrapping of the DIFF scheme. These were the words you used last Tuesday:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . not one minister—be he a foreign minister or an economic development minister—has expressed any concern to me about the abolition of the DIFF program.

Did you not admit to the House last night that you had in fact discussed the abolition of DIFF with Professor Ginandjar, the Indonesian Minister for National Development Planning, and Dr Habibie, the Minister of State for Research and Technology? Aren't they not only the two most important economic development ministers in the Indonesian government but two of the most important and distinguished ministers in the entire government? How could you possibly have forgotten that these two gentlemen met with you, what they said to you and what you said in reply in this your first face to face meeting with them in Jakarta on 16 April?

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave an undertaking to the House during my answer to questions yesterday and during the censure debate that I would check the records in my department on this matter and was quite happy to come back to the House and add anything, and I indeed did that. Frankly, Mr Speaker, I have nothing else to add.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Given that a competitive banking environment provides real benefits for consumers of home mortgage products, can the Treasurer advise the House that the government is intending to take action to further foster competition in the banking sector? If so, can the Treasurer advise what steps the government will be taking and what are the likely benefits for consumers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already made it clear on behalf of the government how we believe it is important to foster competition in the finance industry. As a result of competition in the mortgage industry, we have seen variable mortgage rates decline over recent months. It is the government's intention to increase competition in the banking sector by reforms to the interest withholding tax exemption, section 128F. This is a relic of the tax act from some 20 years ago, legislated for another time and another place.

ANSWER.PARA: The existing exemption arrangements prevented low cost overseas funds being lent to home buyers and consumers, because under the existing law the exemption could only be accessed where overseas borrowings were used for Australian business, that is, they had to be used for business purposes. By removing this requirement, Australian borrowers will be able to apply overseas borrowings for home lending and consumer finance. This was not allowed under the existing law. This will have a noticeable impact on the competitiveness of the home loan lending market and it will give the opportunity for increased competition ultimately to benefit consumers.

We will be ensuring also that fundraising by Australian financial institutions overseas is more transparent and open to further competitive pressures. Under the current IWT exemption, debentures issued by an Australian company overseas must be widely distributed in the retail market. This requirement will be replaced by a public offer test extending the exemption to borrowings on wholesale capital markets. This will ensure that when Australian borrowers—

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister's attention been drawn to certain ministerial omissions which could have invalidated a range of conduct under the Native Title Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to a very serious lapse of ministerial responsibility and behaviour under the Native Title Act. The situation is that, consequent upon the passage of the Native Title Act by this parliament in December 1993, it was an obligation of the then minister, the former member for Robertson, Mr Walker, to issue a determination under that act. I have ascertained on advice that the determination was signed by the minister on 24 December 1993 but, in fact, was never tabled by the former minister. It was signed, I repeat, on 24 December 1993 but was never tabled. The fact that it was never tabled has recently come to the attention of my department, and that advice has been passed to me—
—It has taken three years.

—The member for Fremantle, who is an expert on remembering things, interjects and says, `It has taken three years.' Can I just say that the determination was signed by the former minister, Frank Walker, on 24 December 1993, and the fact that it was not tabled came to light because some amendment to that determination was required. When an amendment of that determination was required, then recourse was had to the record to see the date of the tabling of the original determination. It was ascertained that that had simply not been tabled by the former minister.

ANSWER.PARA: I would have to say that I cannot think of a baser example of ministerial failure than an inability, having signed a document, to even table it. I say to the House that the net effect of the failure of Frank Walker is that he, by that failure, and the former Keating government, by that failure, could well have cast a legal doubt over a large number of acts affecting the Aboriginal community, the pastoral industry and the mining industry as a result. No wonder there has been a decline in confidence in relation to ministerial competence and a decline in the attitude of the community towards ministerial standards. The situation is that Frank Walker failed, having signed the determination, to put it on the table. That has recently been discovered for the reason that I explained.

We will table the determination later this week. Talk about a lapse of time! He signed it in December 1993 and we have to table it, belatedly, on his behalf. He has proved himself to be a rank, incompetent minister. He is an example of the rank, incompetent ministerial standards of the former government. We will table that determination. We will also take advice from the states—from the mining industry, the pastoral industry and the Aboriginal community—as to whether any other patch-up remedial measures are required. I remind the House that the legislation that was meant to be the piece de resistance of the social agenda of the Keating government meant so little to Frank Walker that he even forgot to table a bit of paper.

Minister, you told the House on 18 June, and reaffirmed it in today's article in the Australian , that not one minister raised with you the scrapping of DIFF. Given that you have now acknowledged that at least three ministers have raised it with you, is this what you really meant when you said not one? This is not P.G. Wodehouse; this is Monty Python. If so, are there any more that you have just remembered to compound this double‐speak? Despite the bravado of last week, don't you now concede that there is significant opposition at home and abroad to the decision to scrap the DIFF scheme, and will you review that decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be reviewing the decision. That is the first point. The second thing I would say about the DIFF scheme, as I have made clear all along, is that, inevitably, those who receive the money would rather continue to receive it. Naturally enough, if that is taken away, that is a point of disappointment. We understand that and we accept that.

ANSWER.PARA: We have been left with a simply horrendous budgetary situation in this country. We have been left with an $8 billion hole, and we simply have to make hard decisions. It would be one thing to do what Labor Party suggests we do—that is, not make any hard decisions and walk away from the fiscal problems that we have. The fact is that we have to address those issues.
When it comes to our relationships with those crucially important countries in our region, one of the things they look to is a strong economic performance from this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't even remember talking to them.
—I warn the member for Denison.

—If our economic performance is weak, that will reduce our capacity to engage with the region. That is something that is well and truly understood in the region and why we have to make these sorts of decisions. The opposition leaves us with a problem to fix up. When we start fixing it up, they start complaining, as you would expect. We can only ask, `What would your solution be to an $8 billion hole in the budget deficit?' Would it be increased taxes or would you just leave the $8 billion hole? You answer that question. What is your solution? The answer is that you babble along but you have no solution.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I seek clarification on aspects of the coalition's workplace relations bill as it relates to women. Are claims that the bill will remove paid maternity leave and provisions about predictable part-time work hours from award entitlements correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question seeking clarification. Those claims which are prevalent from opposition members are demonstrably incorrect. Their constant repetition only highlights the fact that they do not have a substantial argu ment against the principal elements of the package that we are putting.

ANSWER.PARA: If you take the two matters which the honourable member has raised, I actually have a document entitled `News alert' from Senator the Hon. Margaret Reynolds. This document of hers is clearly wrong. She says in this document that, under the government's policy proposals, various items will be removed from awards entitlements. For example, she lists paid maternity leave. That is just blatantly wrong. The proposition which the government is putting will see that paid maternity leave is an allowable matter. It is quite specifically mentioned in the list of allowable matters, as are other important entitlements for people, including carers leave, paternity leave and adoption leave, just to mention a number of them.

Senator Reynolds also says that we are removing from awards entitlements the subject of redundancy. That is patently wrong. If the senator cared to read the government's proposals, she would see that redundancy is specifically provided. In fact, it was a matter that was raised with us during the consultation process. We ensured that it was added to the list so as to protect that basic entitlement of people.

Senator Reynolds then goes on to make claims about the impact of the approach that we are taking in respect of part-time work. The claim there generally is that this will place employees essentially at the whim of employers in the times at which they work. That is quite wrong. Not only is it wrong, but it is hypocritical for that claim to be made against the government because we are actually attempting to correct one of the problems in the existing system where we have seen in recent years an explosion in the number of people who are undertaking casual work.

The number of employees involved in casual work has grown from 17 per cent in 1986 under the previous government to 24 per cent of employees in 1995. The reason for that is that there are so many restrictions on the capacity of people to take up part-time work opportunities. We are removing those barriers to those opportunities for people in this proposed legislation. Women who often want to juggle family and work responsibilities are denied those opportunities today by the system which was put in place by the previous government.

As I have demonstrated, these claims are clearly and obviously demonstrably false. These are important issues. We have had a lot of discussion with women's groups about these issues. I can assure the House that we will continue those consultations during the months ahead with the Senate committee process under way. We do so on a genuine basis because we think they are important issues. We want to see the legislation changed in this country to provide real opportunities for a lot of Australians, particularly for women.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel and Acting Minister for Defence. Can the minister inform the House of the compensation payable in respect of those killed in the recent Townsville Black Hawk helicopter accident and the measures being undertaken to counsel and advise those injured and the dependants of those killed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bishop, Bronwyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Herbert for his question because many questions have been asked in the aftermath of the death and the loss of those 18 soldiers as to how their families are being compensated. We said at the time that we would look after those families and we will.

ANSWER.PARA: The compensation comes from three sources: firstly, from the military compensation scheme, with a lump sum payment of $158,000 with $52 per week payable in respect of each child, with 10 per cent for each child being held in trust until they are 18 years old; secondly, there are sums from the superannuation schemes, and there are two of those for dependants; and then there are repatriation benefits available under the VEA scheme, the veterans entitlement scheme, which is applicable to only a small number. All of those calculations are being done and, as we speak, we have a team of people going around and speaking with the dependants so they will know precisely what they are entitled to and when that money will be made available.

Other questions that have been raised include: what is the future of the tenure of the defence housing in which those families presently reside? The ordinary scheme of things provides that families, in the event of death, may remain in that housing for three months. We have doubled that period to six months and, if it is required to be longer, that period will also be made available. Where families are in urgent need of finances, money has already been made available from the army relief trust fund. There is also counselling advice which is going on and will continue to go on as any family is in need of that, together with the advice concerning compensation.

I would just like to also thank my colleague the Minister for Veterans' Affairs for his assistance in this matter. I think that the cooperation that has been had all round from people within the Defence Force is to be commended. Everybody has acted as speedily as they could to ensure that any hardship is minimised and the compassion is really there.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have in the gallery this afternoon Mr Rick Setter MLA, Deputy Speaker of the Northern Territory parliament, three members of the New Zealand parliament, Ian Revell, Mark Burton and Max Bradford, and a former Attorney‐General of this place, the Hon. Michael Lavarch. A very warm welcome to you all.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it the case that Mr Philip Flood, the head of your department and the person who advised you on the appointment of Miles Kupa, was himself our ambassador in Jakarta at the time of the public controversy over the leaking in 1992 of Mr Kupa's strong criticism of the Indonesian leadership? Is it also the case that you were at the time shadow trade minister within the DFAT portfolio? Do you ask this House to believe that not only did you not recall the 1992 controversy but also your department did not remind you or advise you in any way of that controversy and its significance?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 144. This question is clearly an attempt to debate the matter, as have all the other questions, and furthermore is clearly in breach of standing order 144, paragraphs (b), (e) and (f), which relate to arguments, epithets and ironical expressions. On that basis, it should be ruled out of order.
—To that point of order, Mr Speaker: this is, quite clearly, quite pointed questioning.
—Kim, I have heard you argue the opposite case.
—The member for O'Connor is not helping matters!

—Wilson, I know mostly you are on our side these days, but I would be grateful if I could finish the point of order. This is obviously a very serious area of questioning. The questions that have been put down are quite deliberate and quite pointed and do not contain argument. They are ascer taining facts as to the situation of various people involved in this particular incident, followed by a conclusion that is seeking to work out whether or not the minister has revealed all that he might be prepared to reveal or all that he has to reveal in relation to an appointment. —Mr Speaker, on a further point of order: I want to take up that matter and put to you that a question that asks whether or not Mr Flood was the ambassador in 1992 is clearly an argument. In my submission to you, it is merely a disguise for an argument. On that basis, it should be ruled out of order.

—Mr Speaker, to that point of order: virtually every question asked in this place, by definition, is a matter of public record to some degree. If being a matter of public record is a reason to rule a question out of order in this place, we might as well abandon question time.
—I am considering very carefully the various points of order. At the moment, the question, whilst somewhat imprecise, should be directed with greater definition.

—Minister, do you ask the House to believe that your department did not remind or advise you in any way of that controversy and its significance? Will you table all written advice given to you in relation to Mr Kupa's appointment? Will you state today, unequivocally, to this House that you received no advice whatever, written or oral, on this critical aspect of Mr Kupa's nomination?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to answer the question. Let me begin by saying that I have said all along that as the minister I obviously accept the responsibility for the problems that have occurred over Mr Kupa's appointment. That is a principle we apply on this side of the House. I am the minister. I inherited certain procedures from the previous government in terms of appointments. I did not change those procedures; I kept those procedures in place.

ANSWER.PARA: My recollection is—and I think it is correct—that I received a submission from my department, which was signed by Mr Flood, who—you are correct—was the ambassador in Jakarta in 1992. I received a submission from him which had several names on it—and I will not canvass the names because that would be clearly embarrassing to those others involved, but they are all good and proper people—including Mr Kupa's, and it had Mr Kupa's abridged curriculum vitae. I had brief discussions with Mr Flood about this matter. I am not going to reveal the details of those discussions, except to say that this question of the events of 1992 was not raised in those discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about in the brief?
—The member for Hotham!

—It was not raised in the submission and it was not raised orally in any discussions. I am quite happy to add—but all within the context of me accepting full responsibility for this; I am not trying to duckshove the responsibility to anybody else, I accept full responsibility for these problems—that the first I learned of the problems in relation to Mr Kupa's proposed appointment as ambassador to Jakarta was when I was in New York. I was faxed the usual media clippings that my department faxes to wherever I may be. One clipping was from the Sydney Morning Herald referring to the 1992 incident relating to Mr Kupa.

ANSWER.PARA: I had a function to attend. When I returned from the function, I phoned my department in Canberra. There was a discussion about this. When I got back to Australia, I saw Mr Kupa and had a discussion about that, and, I think in a very proper and very decent way, Mr Kupa offered to withdraw from the nomination.

I know there is this argument that you see in Greg Sheridan's columns which is your only source of ideas, as far as I can make out. I said to my staff this morning, after reading Greg Sheridan's column, `I expect he'll get up today and ask: when did I first find out about Miles Kupa and the 1992 events?' You did it because it was there at the bottom of the Greg Sheridan column, wasn't it, `Don't forget, Laurie, to ask Downer that question?' I thought you would do it, and you did it.

It is true that I do not have a recollection of the 1992 events. Of course, as I have explained, my department did not canvass that issue with me. As a matter of fact, after we put the name forward to the Indonesians, to the best of my knowledge—and I tried to check this today with the department after I read the Greg Sheridan column and anticipated your question—I have been told that the Indonesians did not raise this matter either. It was not until after the Sydney Morning Herald article appeared that this matter was given consideration.

I conclude with where I started. Of course I accept responsibility for this. As a consequence of that, I have instituted new procedures to be put in place so that there is better analysis done of, and consideration given to, people who are being put forward for heads of mission appointments, particularly diplomatic appointments.

I conclude with one other point. I accept responsibility for this, but I would also add that this has done not one jot of damage to our bilateral relationship with Indonesia. That is a view that has been confirmed to me from a wide range of sources. It has done not one jot of damage at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Can the minister confirm that up to one in five children leaving primary school do not have adequate reading and writing skills? What action is the government taking to address this major problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Lindsay for her question and her interest in this important matter. I am sure that most members of the House would agree that there are very few more important things than that students should acquire adequate literacy and numeracy skills while at school, and particularly while in primary school. Members of the House who were here in 1992 would remem ber that the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training—a bipartisan committee—stated that up to one in five children may be finishing primary school with literacy problems and that in some schools this number may be as high as even 90 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Illiteracy is a problem which is very difficult to address in high school. If it is not addressed in primary school, it is not effectively addressed at all for the vast majority of students. Estimates of the cost of illiteracy range from $3 billion to $6 billion a year in lost production. It is a significant source of behavioural problems in schools and is, of course, linked to youth unemployment. Evidence suggests that those who have not attained literacy skills in the early years of schooling are less likely to finish year 12 and that those who leave before the end of year 12 are disproportionately represented amongst the young unemployed.
This situation simply cannot be allowed to continue. The government has already initiated the first national English literacy survey for 16 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that all you are going to do—a survey?
—The member for Calwell!
—That was a matter of neglect by the previous government.
—Why don't you do something?
—The member for Calwell will restrain himself.
—I will also be speaking with the deans of education—
—Another survey.
—I warn the member for Calwell.

—to ensure that primary teachers have adequate training to address the literacy needs of their students in primary school. It is important that we go further than this. I am proposing that we set a new national goal for literacy—that all students, when they leave primary school, should have adequate literacy and numeracy skills.
—Are you going to give them the resources?
—Many people in this country would believe that literacy is the first call on the education dollar, not the last call. You have neglected this for 13 years.

BREAK.PARA: There is a further aspect to this problem that I would like to inform the House about. It relates to the $2 billion man sitting on the other side of the House. One of the first things that seemed to us important to do was to get some research undertaken on the precise relationship between literacy problems and youth unemployment.

I was aware of the fund known as the projects for national significance fund, which had about $2.8 million in it to be spent during this calendar year. When I asked the department, `Why don't we initiate some research on the linkage between literacy and youth unemployment,' they said, `Well, Minister, it is doubtful that there would be enough money left in that fund to do that.' Of course, I asked, `How could it possibly be? This is the fund for the calendar year. The election was called at the end of January; how could it be that there is almost no money left in this fund?'

It turns out that after eight per cent of the year had passed, a portion of the month of January, some 76 per cent—$2 million—of the funds had already been spent. That shows that no sum is either too large, whether it be $2 billion, or too small, whether it be $2 million, for these people not to have spent in the run‐up to the election to try to protect their own hides.

It turns out that $600,000 of this fund was spent on the last working day before the election was called. The member for Hotham must have known what was coming up. He certainly knew how to spend the money. He did that at the expense of the unemployed in this country. He did that at the expense of the training providers. He did that at the expense of allowing the new government to undertake research into this important matter by using this fund.

This government regards literacy as a central priority and is committed to working with the states and territories, regardless of the neglect of the last 13 years, to ensure that learning levels and literacy levels are improved amongst all Australian students.

Do you recall telling this House last Tuesday that the decision to scrub the DIFF program was made `before the last election'? Do you recall that decision in fact being announced by the member for Higgins in his `Meeting Our Commitments' statement on 15 February, well before the last election and your discovery of so-called black holes? The point is that, yes, it is true; we did announce that the program would be abolished in `Meeting our Commitments'. Then the member for Hotham says, `Will we reinstate it?' Will we reinstate it when you have left us with an $8 billion black hole? Really and truly, how irresponsible can you get? You people—the member for Holt, the member for Kingsford-Smith, the member for Perth, the Leader of the Opposition—are effectively arguing that we should reinstate this program. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Can the minister inform the House of the government's progress in relation to the implementation of the coalition's election commitment to the upgrade of the Pacific Highway?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Richmond for his question. Indeed, he along with a number of his colleagues—the member for Cowper, who has been campaigning on the Pacific Highway for the whole of the period that he has been in the parliament, some 11½ years; the member for Lyne, who has been raising this issue as a very high priority in his own electorate; the member for Page, who has been bringing this issue forward as an important issue for his electorate; and, of course, the member for Paterson, who has also highlighted this as a very important issue in his electorate—have been highlighting the concerns of the Pacific Highway for the period that they have been in the parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: And well they might because, as members of the House would know, the Pacific Highway has been the subject of the worst road accidents that we have seen in this country over the last number of years. There have been some 600 deaths on the Pacific Highway in the last 10 years and some 10,000 people injured on that highway over the last 10 years. Of course, the proof of that is in the quality and standard of the road itself. Anybody who has travelled on it will know it is a very poor standard road that services the fastest growing areas in Australia. So there has been a need to upgrade that road.

In the last election campaign, the Prime Minister—I think it might have been in the honourable member for Richmond's electorate—announced a coalition commitment to allocate $750 million over a period of 10 years and that this would be matched by the state governments in Queensland and New South Wales on a pro rata basis. Ultimately, with the funds that the two state governments had already committed to works on that highway, that would see some $3.1 billion allocated by the three levels of government over the 10‐year period.

It was a very important initiative undertaken by us and, of course, it is one that we treat with great seriousness. We indicated at the time that we would be identifying the three worst black spots on the Pacific Highway—the Chinderah-Billinudgel section, the Brunswick Heads bypass and also the Possums Brush‐Coolongolook‐Bulahdelah section, all of which are well‐known black spots on that highway and, indeed, recognised as the worst sections on the Pacific Highway.

People have become somewhat cynical about promises in regard to the Pacific Highway. People will recall that in 1990 the former Labor Commonwealth government made a commitment to allocate $100 million a year for 10 years to upgrade the Pacific Highway. We had the experience of a former Labor government promising, from 1990 onwards, to spend money on the roads. People were concerned because, what happened when Labor got into office after the 1990 election? Did they deliver on their promises to put $100 million into the Pacific Highway for the next 10 years? The answer is: no, they did not.

Today I am very pleased to inform the House that the New South Wales Minister for Roads, Michael Knight, has announced the New South Wales government's intention, along with the Commonwealth's, to commit to the Pacific Highway the funds that were outlined by me just a few moments ago. The Minister for Roads in New South Wales, Michael Knight, has indicated that they will be addressing the Coolongolook to Bulahdelah section first, and also the Brunswick Heads bypass. I note that the New South Wales minister has not announced at this stage the Chindera to Billinudgel section of that Pacific Highway upgrade.

I call on the Minister for Roads in the New South Wales parliament, Mr Michael Knight, to join with us in our commitment to that road. I know the honourable member for Richmond is totally and utterly committed to the upgrading of that section of road—indeed, a complete new realignment for that section of road—that will lead to a large reduction in the number of deaths and injuries that occur on it.

I ask the New South Wales minister, Mr Knight, to join with us in that commitment to the Chindera‐Billinudgel section of the Pacific Highway, to upgrade it to ensure that we reduce the number of deaths and injuries on the Pacific Highway.

I suppose it is no surprise, given the record of the former Minister for Foreign Affairs, that they gave him a Treasury job.

There is a lot of evidence, anecdotal recorded evidence, that that law of Labor's—the Brereton law on unfair dismissal—has actually been a major disincentive to job creation. The sooner we chuck out his law and replace it with a fairer law, which is what we propose to do, then the better chance there will be that people are going to have jobs.

Look at what we are doing in the training area: that again is going to free up a lot of opportunities for people to get a job and some training to go with it. The great thing about that is that it opens up prospects for people to earn more in the future and make a real contribution to our small businesses. On the Mornington Peninsula, where vignerons, for example, have a growing industry dovetailing with the tourist industry, there are tremendous job prospects for growth, for higher wages for people in the future—opportunities that have been denied by the previous government.

Lastly, I could not sit down without mentioning the plight of young people in particular. We have in so many parts of regional and rural Australia very high levels of unemployment amongst young people, and they are very concerned that if Labor's scheme to abolish junior wage rates were to come into place next year then a lot more young people would in fact lose their jobs. For that reason we are moving to shut off that particular time bomb ticking under the Brereton legislation.

Are we directed to helping small business? Absolutely yes. Will this industrial relations package be a great benefit to small business? Absolutely yes. That is why we are determined to seek its early passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Minister for Foreign Affairs for:

(1) repeated failure, in responses to questions on the status of regional opinion about the abolition of the DIFF program, to inform the House of his discussions with two senior Indonesian Economic Development Ministers;
(2) for misleading an important regional neighbour and trading partner, and the Australian public, about the reasons for abolishing DIFF; and
(3) for gross incompetence in his mishandling of his portfolio and Australia's relationship with our Asian neighbours.

We are moving this motion in the context of having moved a censure motion on the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) yesterday. Subsequent to that censure motion, in which he based his defence entirely around the notion of some form of status for the vice minister in China in the foreign affairs and trade portfolio, he came into this chamber and said, `Oh, by the way, just to correct the record, I did have a conversation on these matters with the two most senior economic development ministers in Indonesia a couple of months ago.'

Let us recollect where that position came from. It came from a series of answers given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in the course of the previous weeks in which he denied up hill and down dale that he had been the recipient of any senior level approaches, had engaged in any senior level discussions on these matters with those representatives. It would be very simple for him to come in here today and say, `Oh, by the way, when I said "by the way" about that last night, I was talking about a piece of advice which triggered my memory after question time yesterday that I had had those conversations.' In question time yesterday we put a persistent series of questions, as we had before, to the Minister for Foreign Affairs as to whether or not to his knowledge there had been, or whether or not he could recollect, any sets of conversations he had had with people on this absolutely vital matter of national importance.

The DIFF program is no joke. This program has become central to our aid program over the last many years now and it is one of those elements of our aid program which builds a very substantial level of confidence in our region in Australian business. It is one of those things that, when you go out to the public and defend our foreign aid program, you are able to point out is not only a question of largess and basic human decency, important though they are in a foreign aid program, but also a matter of advancing Australian interests and Australian jobs.

BREAK.PARA: This is a serious program. The level of objection which the Minister for Foreign Affairs has received indicates how well received it is. He has received objections now from the very highest level of the Chinese government and, he admits to us, from the very highest level of the Indonesian government. But here he has squirmed away from his lying to this House a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition will be very careful with the words he is using.

—He deceived this House for a second time. It would have been the easiest thing, if it had struck his mind, for him to stand up in this place and say, `Look, I found out about this after question time yesterday.' But he did not do that. He said that `sometime this week' he had been advised.

BREAK.PARA: That is absolutely critical. That is why there is a question time. That is why you are accountable in this place at question time. You are allowed to evade answers, if you wish. But, when you do give answers, you are obliged to give precise and accurate ones. In this debate you are not in a situation where you are permitted to slip slide away—to come into this place and say, `Oh, well, sometime this week.' If it happened to be that you received that advice before question time yesterday, then on those grounds you are, in addition, culpable for having deceived this House, for having misled the public and for having misled Australia. You have committed again, for the second time, a most serious dereliction of your duty to this chamber as a minister.

It is not often in censure motions in this chamber that we get a serious censure motion. Generally speaking, the moving of a censure motion in the Australian parliament is the sort of thing that is done at the end of a session. You may be dealing with some aspect of the government's handling of the economy and you have run out of being able to use the MPIs for those sorts of processes, so you get into the chamber and move a censure motion on the handling of the economy or something like that. I am afraid to say that, over the years, the censure motion has become much devalued currency indeed. What the censure motion, properly used, is really about in this chamber is going to the heart of the accountability of a minister and a government—accountability for their performance and their willingness to adhere to the standards that have been set them.

Where has this minister failed to adhere to the standards? Firstly, he failed last week. For that, we moved this proposition yesterday. He is being mocked in the media today—not simply by Greg Sheridan and everybody who chooses to abuse this place, but by virtually every other journalist who carries the parliamentary pages. They can see, even if the foreign minister cannot, that a letter which is signed on behalf of a minister is a letter from a minister. They can see that; he cannot, apparently, see that. He has got up and fessed up, effectively, to misleading on that point.

Then he came into this chamber last night and put down the most revealing and pathetic excuse. Whatever interpretation you might have about Madam Wu and the way in which she conducts her correspondence, whatever view you might have of Minister Wu on whether or not she really corresponds with you when she corresponds through one of her vice ministers, you cannot possibly have that view of Professor Ginandjar and Dr Habibie.

Nobody who knows anything about Indonesia fails to know those two gentlemen. Those two gentlemen are not only their nation's senior economic development ministers; those two gentlemen are often touted in the media as potential presidents of their nation. I said yesterday I did not find it terribly surprising that the foreign minister could come into this place and say, `Well, no, I haven't been approached by people at ministerial level,' and to sort of wrap that smarmy scarf around himself that he does and say, `Maybe it's been raised with junior officials but it's never been raised with me.' That does not surprise me.

This is the first meeting he has had with these gentlemen. The normal way of being dealt with in this region is that you do not put on the table difficult things for a first meeting. They are trying to get to know you. They are trying to get to understand you. They are trying to see where you come from. It is a most unusual thing for them to put any matter of controversy on the table. They assume that you have a degree of intelligence. When you come in, they make that basic assumption—they assume that you have a degree of intelligence. They assume that, when you approach them and have been advised by your advisers about their concerns, you know about them and do not need to be reminded. Maybe, just maybe, over lunch they might quietly mention these matters to you. But, if they mention them at all, it is most unusual.

What you came into this place and fessed up to yesterday was the fact that you had had a conversation with two senior ministers—and if they raise such matters with you in your first meeting, by golly, they mean it. If they are in a position where they will step aside from normal processes in this region and raise with you a controversial matter, you know this is something they believe to be a very serious matter indeed. `Oh,' you said, as you came in yesterday, `I had a few brief remarks referred to me by them in the course of that.'

Then you found yourself trapped. How did you try to get out of that incredible trap yesterday? You said, `I was not lying to you, I was not deceiving you, because I have decided to close the envelope.' So it does not matter that we announced that the DIFF program was gone on 15 February. No, the time the DIFF program went was really 16 May when we made an announcement about it then. It was really in existence until that point of time—not under any threat at all at that point of time. No, the DIFF program was out there singing and dancing.

So obviously Minister Habibie, Minister Ginandjar and probably also Minister Wu were dragging it out of the heavens—it came down along with the mandate and was something that they could raise with you by virtue of the fact that they have third, fourth, fifth and sixth sight. No, Minister, they raised it with you because you had announced that program. However, I guess what we will get is for you to stand up here and say, `Well, you know, between the dates of 16 May and 17 May or at precisely 12.01 on 17 May, I did not receive any serious approaches from any minister concerning that DIFF program.'

No. You redefined it yesterday. That was not defined that way in any question that has been directed to you or any answer that you have given. That was a convenient little slip slide on 16 May which you decided you would just try to skate away with—just as you have been trying to skate away with every foreign policy boo‐boo, faux pas, that you have managed to commit since you have had this job. So you redefined it. Well, you might redefine it because, at the very least, if you fail to convince anybody that you redefined it—if you fail to convince anybody that somewhere or other embedded in those questions, embedded in the answer, is the ice that you gave them to skate on—you have lied twice.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition will withdraw that.
—I withdraw it. You have deceived twice. He has used this expression in the chamber.
—We will follow that through a little later.

—I have sat on the other side of the House over the years on the other end of censure motions and have constantly been described as a liar and have constantly had Speakers uphold that. Evidently, in the censure motion we are never allowed to use it.
—We will address this problem later. Proceed with the censure motion.
—This deceitful minister has deceived twice—deliberately misled twice.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition is continuing to use unparliamentary language. We will address this question a little later. As you well know, unparliamentary language is not acceptable.
—This is a censure motion.
—Even in the heat of a censure motion. We will not debate the issue. This is your time.

—I am not going to argue with you, Mr Speaker. I think we have a very good Speaker on our hands. I disagree absolutely with the proposition that you put forward, but I will take my argument up with you in another place.

BREAK.PARA: The minister has misled twice. He misled once last week when he gave that answer on Minister Wu and he misled again yesterday. The consequences of that misleading ought to be severe for any minister. He chose yesterday not to defend himself but to attack the former Minister for Transport, the now shadow minister for foreign affairs, the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton). His method of defence was not one that you would normally mount in these sorts of matters; it was an attack. He will need to do a great deal better than that today because he has now added to the record very dramatically.

Go back over the questions that he answered and look at his defence on this most serious matter. He has been on the back foot for the last few months as far as DIFF is concerned. He has sought a defence in the view that this is not taken terribly seriously. He has sought under constant pressure—it is not as though we have asked him no questions on this—to have the view abroad that, even though this is a bit of a problem, it is being handled effectively at the lower levels and it is not something that need impinge upon the relationship between the senior figures in government.

On that defence he bases the notion that he is an acceptable foreign minister. On that defence he bases the notion that he is capable of handling the issues of survival for the Australian nation. The Minister for Foreign Affairs handles the issues of survival for the Australian nation. His relationship with the countries in the region is critical. His ability to deal honestly with the Australian people is critical.

What we find is sleight of hand, tossed off; on a couple of occasions he comes into this chamber and fesses up. He did not accept the view that he had offended in any way. He chose to interpret what is blindingly obvious to absolutely everyone around this place as something different—black was white as far as he was concerned.

The second time round he could not get away with that. There is absolutely no way you can describe those two officials from Indonesia as anything other than precisely the sort of people he had denied he had ever discussed these matters with. He invented another block in the process to explain a set of totally and utterly inaccurate answers in this House. That second block was to put that proposition down about the 16th. He compounded all of this by misleading the Chinese, Indonesians and everybody else as to the true reasons they arrived at the position they arrived at on DIFF.

What is critical in his failure to answer the questions that I have just put to him—and you would have to say that if the answer were not bad then he would have had no compunction in giving it—is that, had he been advised by his department of the existence of those conversations prior to the answers that he gave in question time yesterday, then he has, under any conceivable interpretation, under any interpretation that can be put down by anybody who has ever debated a censure motion in this chamber or anywhere else that devotes itself to the Westminster system, gone on immediate advice and walked into the chamber and been unwilling to accept the embarrassment. He has concealed the source of that embarrassment and misled this House in the grossest possible way. That is completely inconsistent with his oath of office and with the obligations that are imposed upon him by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

For that reason alone, and on hearing this debate and hearing question time, the Prime Minister would be obliged to pick up the phone and ring the minister the moment he leaves this chamber and tell him, `You are on a week's notice. We will find some way of getting you through, Alexander, until this week is over so that we do not take too much embarrassment, but after that you are the ambassador to the Netherlands.' That is what ought to occur if that happens to be the case.

Even if he is now able, having ducked the opportunity to clear his name twice in question time, to get up and say sotto voce, if he is capable of sotto voce in this place, `No, I did not receive that information until yesterday afternoon, after question time. My memory was triggered then.' he still should be censured by this place for what he revealed yesterday afternoon and his continuing failure to give a satisfactory explanation on anything other than a defeat on party lines on the earlier point.

The point about all of this—and we have to get back to this to set the scene for the seriousness of all of this—is the position they hold on DIFF. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—There can be few issues that touch the public closer than the safety of our public transport. And one of its most sensitive aspects, where there has been grave concern for some time now, is aviation safety.

SPEECH.PARA: On 3 May 1994 I rose in this House to speak on the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1994 and addressed in my speech the matter of the Monarch air crash that took place at Young, on 11 June 1993, killing all five passengers, the pilot and the co‐pilot. I took a close interest in that tragedy because all the passengers were known to me and most of them were my constituents.

It is now over three years after that air crash and, on 6 June this year, the New South Wales coroner delivered his findings at the Young courthouse, following one of the longest coronial inquests in this country's history. His findings have confirmed many of the concerns that I put before the House on 3 May, two years earlier. I told the House then that the Civil Aviation Authority had been aware for some time of the deficiencies of Monarch Air and that, despite recommendations by airworthiness inspectors to ground the operator, these recommendations had been overruled by senior management. I told the House that:

The CAA has obviously fallen down in its prime responsibility to conduct safety regulation of civil air operations in Australia. It has no excuses. The CAA has been given the teeth. The problem is that it is not using them. My constituents, through no fault of their own, flew in an aircraft that operated and that the CAA knew was likely to operate in breach of air safety regulations and were the victims of a fatal accident.

I also alerted the House to the fact that the Monarch case was not the iceberg itself but merely the tip of the iceberg. I cited another airline—Seaview—which was also being allowed to operate despite the recommendation of an airworthiness inspector to ground it. I told the House:

The CAA has been aware of the situation for some time and, once again, nothing has been done to stop that operator from risking the lives of the unwitting passengers despite a CAA airworthiness inspector's recommendation that the operator be grounded.

In the week before I made that speech, a DC3 had crashed into Botany Bay narrowly avoiding sending its 21 passengers—a school party on their way to Norfolk Island to participate in Anzac Day celebrations—to their deaths. My warning regarding Seaview was not heeded. On 2 October 1994, a Seaview plane crashed on its way to Lord Howe Island killing all eight passengers and the pilot.

It is one of the great tragedies of our time that it took the senseless and needless deaths of 16 people to provoke action to deal with the situation that I put before the House on 3 May 1994: that the CAA had clearly lost sight of its primary responsibility for the maintenance of air safety above all other considerations.

When I brought that state of affairs to the attention of the House on 3 May, I said that there were several measures that were essential. I said then that the first action must be for the government to review the priorities of the Civil Aviation Authority. I said that it must investigate the association between flying operations inspectors and airline operators to ensure that no opportunity for corruption can occur. I said that viability must be included among mandatory criteria when the Civil Aviation Authority is considering an air operator's certificate. I also said that insurance arrangements should be changed so that unscrupulous insurance firms cannot weasel their way out of their obligations by claiming that the operator breached safety regulations, thus voiding the policy at the expense of the victims.

Subsequently, I called for the removal of certain senior managers. It is unfortunate that the culture that then existed in the CAA involving a disposition to shoot the messenger rather than to listen to the message prevailed for some time despite the advice that I gave the then minister immediately following my speech in the House on 3 May. I advised the minister that he should separate the regulatory function of the CAA from its commercial service provider functions and should subject the organisation to rigorous examination. I offered him my bipartisan support in doing so.

On the release of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation report on the Monarch accident in July 1994, the then minister announced the separation of the regulatory function from the commercial function, but under the same chief executive officer. At the same time, he announced a reference to the House of Representatives Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for an inquiry into aviation safety in general aviation.

The inquiry became one of the most remarkable the committee has undertaken. Chaired by the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), it heard some extraordinary stories and was witness to some of the most acrimonious evidence that could possibly be given to a parliamentary inquiry. The evidence led the committee to conclude that the CAA was an organisation at civil war with itself. It was clear that there were enormous problems based around personalities and interest groups which greatly reduced the effectiveness and capacity of the organisation to perform its duties.

BREAK.PARA: In the chaos that ensued following the Seaview crash, the government of the day finally introduced legislation splitting the CAA into two separate organisations—much as I had suggested to the then minister in May. The House of Representatives Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure was closely involved in the refinement of the legislation, and the resultant bills gave rise to the new organisations known as the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and Airservices Australia—the former regulating aviation safety and the latter providing commercial services.

I have the greatest regard for my colleagues on that committee, and participants in and users of aviation in this country are indebted to them for the work they have done in identifying many of the issues in aviation safety regulation that urgently need improvement. Their report, Plane safe, has made many concrete recommendations, and the government will be responding to these shortly. That response will be a thorough one and a draft is currently undergoing several revisions that I have requested.

One of the most important initiatives to come from the Plane safe report will be a system of public reporting of serious deficiencies found by CASA in individual air operators. This will enable travellers to be informed as to the record of a particular operator. It will also mean that, if a particular operator contravenes regulations, they will pay the price in lost reputation and lost consumer confidence, with market consequences for them.

One of the hardest things for the victims of aviation tragedies—such as the Monarch and Seaview tragedies—to understand is that they live with the consequences of those tragedies daily, yet the operators and regulators who failed to do their jobs properly and who erred seriously in their duty of care seem to escape any consequences. Three years after the Monarch accident none of those who were negligent have been brought to account.

One of the first principles of regulation should be that the regulators themselves are accountable for their actions. They should be congratulated when their efforts to maintain safe travel are properly, carefully and fairly carried out. They should also be accountable when their failure to do so leads to tragedy or when their failure to do so exposes the very people they are supposed to be protecting to danger.

The Monarch coroner's findings have made specific criticisms—some of them about particular people and some of them about the organisation itself. The coroner has made several recommendations, some of which, such as those relating to insurance, have already been implemented. It is now mandatory for aviation operators carrying passengers for financial reward to have non‐voidable insurance for their passengers. That has not helped the victims of the Monarch crash, who are still waiting for acknowledgment and settlement of their claims against the insurer of the operator. The changes to the legislation were made necessary largely because of the disgraceful treatment they have suffered, and still suffer, at the hands of Monarch's insurer.

There are other recommendations of the coroner that fall within the federal jurisdiction. I am referring them to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and Airservices Australia for urgent advice and action.

This government is determined to ensure that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority will not repeat the errors of its predecessor. I personally have a great deal of commitment to this. I have made it clear to the Director of Aviation Safety that I expect his officers to be fully accountable for their actions. There is no place in the new CASA for officers who hide behind a cloak of intimidation and secrecy to avoid the consequences of their failure to carry out their duties to the highest standards.

The Bureau of Aviation Safety Investigation report into the DC3 crash in Botany Bay, released earlier this year, identified several major systemic failures within the CAA and I have sought detailed explanations from the Director of Aviation Safety of what measures are being taken to identify why those failures occurred and who was responsible for them. I am not yet satisfied that everything that should be done to overcome them has been done.

Indeed, the report that CASA prepared for me has raised several issues that I wish to pursue further with the director before I will be satisfied that the problems that led to such major bungles as incorrect classification of the aircraft and improper extensions of engine hours have been adequately addressed and those responsible held appropriately to account.I am concerned that the old culture still exists despite the change of name.

One of the most unsatisfactory elements of the old CAA was that its officers seemed to believe that they were somehow immune to the consequences of their own wrongdoing. That attitude will have to be well and truly purged from the new CASA. It is the job of the government to ensure that this happens and this government will not be repeating the errors of the previous government in allowing that attitude to continue uncorrected. The Monarch coroner noted:
There is no satisfactory explanation as to why the CAA refused to suspend Monarch's AOC before the crash.

He also spoke of an atmosphere of intimidation of officers who sought to take such action, and referred particularly to a memorandum of a particular officer as having a threatening tone. That kind of intimidation has no place in CASA, or any other responsible organisation.

Further, the coroner identified the Flying Operations Manager at Bankstown as having decided to take no action on the recommendation of an airworthiness inspector to revoke or suspend Monarch's air operator certificate, which had been made only a couple of weeks before the crash. Since the coroner concluded:

It is clear that had the CAA management paid more attention to the law and less to accommodating their "customers", NDU (the aircraft that crashed) would have been grounded and AOC suspended until the plane was safe to fly and these deaths would have been avoided.

This raises serious issues that have yet to be resolved but which must be resolved if the public is to have full confidence in the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. The government agrees with the coroner that the culture that prevailed in the CAA was absolutely unacceptable. It is unacceptable in the CAA's successor regulatory body CASA and the government insists that this be absolutely clear and be seen to be so.

The coroner praised the Reason model of investigation and analysis utilised by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, yet counsel for the CAA spent a great deal of time and effort and taxpayers' money during the coronial inquest in seeking to discredit it. It is just that kind of self‐interested defensive reaction—at the expense of the taxpayer and the industry—that must be shunned if the public is to have faith in the regulator.

It does not make sense for the regulator to spend more money in defending itself than the claims it was seeking to forestall would have amounted to. All that does is deny the victims' families their due compensation. There must be an open and honest culture, and that is still lacking in the Civil Aviation Safety Authority.

This government expects its safety regulator to admit its errors when appropriate and to take remedial measures to reform its culture in order to make it properly responsive to its very weighty responsibilities. The CAA was dismantled and split into CASA and Airservices Australia, but many of the people who were responsible for the dereliction of duty and the perversion of regulatory responsibility that gave rise to the Monarch, the DC3 and the Seaview accidents, as well as to countless other debacles, are still with the new regulator. It will be a major tragedy if the only thing that happens is that the shingle on the front door is changed.

The Director of CASA has already taken some measures towards cultural change. The government will be ensuring that the change continues and is achieved without delay. I noted in June last year during the debate on the legislation establishing CASA that a great deal of expectation and hope would rest upon the shoulders of the board of CASA. That board, I said, would need to be expert and effective.

This government went into the last election with a campaign commitment to ensure that the board of CASA had the necessary aviation experience to ensure expert and effective oversight of aviation safety. The present board does not in the opinion of the government contain that expertise. There is only one of the four non‐executive members of the board with aviation expertise and this is, in the view of the government, inadequate.

On coming into government I made this position clear to the board. The chairman chose not to accede to my request to the board to offer their resignations. In putting their own interests ahead of the need to have the best available people with appropriate expertise and qualifications, the board members were effectively putting their own needs ahead of aviation safety.

Accordingly, the government has introduced legislation which will enlarge the board by two members, one of them in the new position of deputy chairman, to enable the appointment of people with appropriate expertise. I hope that this move to bring to the board of CASA greater expertise and depth will find bipartisan support from the opposition. The people of Australia are entitled to the very highest standards in aviation safety regulation and therefore those who are in charge of that regulatory function must have appropriate qualifications. If CASA is to be able to perform its task adequately, it must be governed by a board that is able to give it expert direction.

The next stage of the change of culture will be reviews of the regulatory framework and of the regulatory role. On 28 June, I will launch some important initiatives towards this end. They will involve the industry itself, through a series of technical committees, in reviewing and writing the rules that govern civil aviation.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communication and Infrastructure found in its inquiry into aviation safety that there was enormous confusion about the rules and regulations governing aviation safety not only among those participating in the industry but also among those regulating it. The rules conflict, are often ambiguous and are interpreted differently in different areas. The review of the rules will clarify them and rewrite them in ways that ensure they are comprehensible and consistent.

The new government has recognised that the regulatory framework has grown out of outdated regulations with various amendments over the years and that this needs a complete overhaul. This overhaul will be done with full industry participation and leadership. That overhaul will not be effective, however, without a complete and complementary change in the way CASA goes about its business.

On 28 June, the Director of CASA and I will be seeking the comments of industry and its support for the proposed reviews. In particular, we will be seeking a commitment from industry to nominate appropriate representatives to the program advisory panel to oversee the reviews. That panel will nominate people from the industry with the appropriate expertise to work on the technical committees which are a key part of the regulatory framework program.

Industry will have an opportunity to have its input into the direction of the program and the timetable for change and to accept responsibility for applying the new rules in their own environment. However, the greatest challenge will be for CASA itself to accept a new culture of accountability not only to me as the minister responsible but also to the parliament and ultimately to the people of Australia.

The Monarch and Seaview deaths were a shocking waste and have left continuing heartbreak and tragedy for the families of the victims. The only recompense we can give them is the certainty that the lessons have been learnt and action taken to ensure that those tragedies are not repeated. When I spoke in support of the legislation creating CASA, I pledged to continue to act as a watchdog over its operations and to be vigilant. I said that I hoped that others associated with the industry would also be vigilant.

I have now been given a ministerial responsibility that makes that pledge and hope a duty—and one I am determined to fulfil. This government is fully committed to that goal. It will not allow the deaths of the victims of Monarch and Seaview tragedies to have been entirely in vain.

The review that I will launch on 28 June will be the most significant step taken towards ensuring aviation safety for many years and it will be accompanied by this government's insistence on the full accountability of our aviation safety regulators. There is much to do until we can be assured that there will not be another repetition of Monarch and Seaview. I present the following paper:

We are left in the dark as to whether the particular problems that have been identified, for example, by the coroner in the Monarch inquiry, Peter Gould, are continuing—whether the same lax approach to safety and the disregard of safety regulation in response to commercial pressures are happening now.
