He states that officers of the then Civil Aviation Authority felt `somehow immune to consequences of their own wrongdoing' and that the government `will not be repeating the errors of the previous government in allowing that attitude to continue uncorrected'. The opposition finds it disturbing that the minister appears to be saying that these problems are continuing and yet is proposing a review of the regulations but does not suggest that he will be doing anything about the people in the Civil Aviation Safety Authority itself.

The opposition finds it disturbing that a very substantial accusation is being levelled on a continuing basis against hardworking and loyal officers of the Commonwealth government in CASA without that being substantiated by contemporary events. It is worrying that we have a minister who is responsible for the performance of the organisation continuing to undermine the organisation, continuing to attack the organisation from above. It would be helpful if the minister realised that he is no longer the shadow minister and that he now has a responsibility for the organisation and for its public performance.

It is significant that the minister refers to the board of CASA: as he himself admitted, not one of his best performances. I remind the House that after becoming minister he asked the board—first on the phone, then in a meeting, then by letter—all to resign. The only reason he gave for this requested resignation was, `I have obligations to other people.' In other words: `I want to put some other people on the board.'

The board members had been in office for nine months. To this day there is no substantial complaint laid against them with respect to their handling of their responsibilities. Disasters such as the Seaview and Monarch tragedies occurred two or three years ago, well outside the time they have been responsible for the authority, yet the minister has the gall to come into this House and accuse them of `putting their own interests ahead of the interests of aviation safety'. This is an outrageous and baseless accusation against people who have been doing a dedicated and thorough job, and no evidence has been advanced in the House today by the minister to support it.

I acknowledge that the coalition policy prior to the election was to ensure that more aviation expertise was represented on the board of CASA. This promise, along with a number of others, was linked to the strong support that the minister and the coalition received from the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association—headed by Dick Smith—in the course of that election. The Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association has been in a state of direct conflict with CASA on a variety of issues, including electronic located transmitters, the labelling of seat belts, conflict of interest allegations with respect to CASA inspectors, the overall cost of safety regulation and the like.

The Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association represents a particular segment of the aviation industry, and it has strong views. It has been very supportive of the minister, and the minister so far in his agenda in this area has been very supportive of AOPA—no more so than endeavouring to rid himself and them of the existing board of CASA. The main reason that has been given is that the board members lack the expertise to fulfil their responsibilities. They are Justice Bill Fisher, a judge; Clare Pollock, a systems safety expert; Gabi Hollows, a consumer advocate; and Geoff Molloy, a retired pilot. All of these have some relevance to the role of CASA. They are not all aviation experts, but they do have relevance. The judge obviously has legal expertise.

Perhaps I should remind the minister, because he may not be aware of this, that the systems safety expert, Dr Clare Pollock, actually studied under Professor James Reason. He may know—in fact, I think he might have even referred to it—about the Reason method of pursuing a disaster inquiry. Professor Reason was the person who headed the inquiry into the Manchester plane fire disaster. Systems safety is a critical area of CASA's responsibility. So, contrary to the sorts of stories that have been put around, Dr Pollock has very directly relevant expertise to the role of CASA. Safety is CASA's business. Consumer advocacy also has a significant responsibility.

The opposition's view is that we do not object to the extension of the board. We do not object to the CASA board having additional people of aviation background on the board, but we do say that generalist skills as well as aviation skills are needed. Aviation, like many other industries, is riddled with sectional interests, with competing factions and competing claims. The last thing that we want to see in our community is a board of the safety regulator become a battleground for competing sectional interests within the industry. That is why you do need some people on the board who are at arms length from those competing claims and competing interests, who can take an independent role but who have the general expertise. If you look throughout the community I doubt, for example, whether you will see too many former iron workers on the board of BHP.

The minister might well ask why it is that he has appointed a geneticist as the head of his department if he is so keen on making sure that people have direct hands-on experience. It is interesting to see some of the transcripts. I should add that I applaud the appointment of Dr Hawke. He is an excellent choice but, of course, he is not a pilot or a mariner or a train driver. On the minister's logic, perhaps he should be.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's an expert public servant.

—That is exactly right. On the Ita Buttrose program some months ago, the minister very deliberately obfuscated on this issue and effectively implied that board members of CASA are actually out there checking planes. That was the effect of what he was saying, which is, quite clearly, very deliberately misleading the public in order to pursue the agenda that he has with respect to their future.

BREAK.PARA: The opposition does not oppose the CASA bill to expand the board, but what it does oppose is adding advocates of sectional interests within the aviation industry to the board. In our view, it is highly inappropriate for a high profile campaigner or lobbyist to be appointed to this position because CASA makes very difficult decisions—decisions which affect the livelihoods of people within the industry, decisions which affect the lives of people who are affected by the industry. To turn the industry regulator into a battleground for sectional interests within the industry would be a disaster.

For that reason, we will oppose the amendment that has been mooted to give the minister power to sack the board for six months. For that reason, we oppose the suggestion of Dick Smith being appointed to the board, and it would be good if the minister would come clean on whether or not he intends to appoint Mr Smith to the board. For that reason, the opposition does not support the so-called affordable safety philosophy that has been advocated by Dick Smith. I would like to quote very briefly from the report of the coroner, Mr Peter Gould, into the Monarch crash. At page 8 of his report, it states:

A former Chairman of the CAA had advocated a policy of "affordable safety" which favoured a very lenient approach to policing the regulations . . . senior echelons of the CAA placed undue emphasis on promoting a "viable" industry and as a consequence were loathe to prosecute airlines for breaches of the Regulations or to revoke an AOC and this had its effect on the Airworthiness and Flight Operations Branches which were responsible for policing the Regulations. Internal memos passing between inspectors show that they resented the restrictions imposed on them by their superiors. An inspector at Wagga Wagga who took a hard line on enforcing safety regulations alleges he was victimised by his superiors and transferred from his position. The effect of all this was that inspectors were unable to take any action against airlines for breaches of the regulations apart from giving warnings and so-called counselling.
Again, at page 50, it states:
The pilots and LAME's were also in breach of their duties in not standing up to McLean's interference.

It is inexcusable but it is understandable. They all knew that there were plenty of unemployed pilots and engineers to take their place if they did resist McLean. They probably had a pretty good hunch that the CAA would do absolutely nothing to protect them if they stuck their necks out and insisted on the CAA Regulations being complied with.
Finally, at page 73, it states:

Mr Dick Smith, Chairman of CAA from 1991-1992 gives evidence that there is a gross misallocation of resources spent on safety surveillance and is of the opinion that it should be left to each operator to determine the "level of safety" at which its planes will fly so long as the public are duly informed in which case, he suggests, many people would be happy to pay another $100 more and have the higher level of safety if and when they can choose.

It is clear that the coroner believes that the Smith administration of the Civil Aviation Authority was central to the Monarch crash and the failure of regulatory standards which were associated with that crash. I ask the minister: will he appoint Mr Dick Smith as one of the new board members if the legislation is passed by this parliament?

There is an enormous contradiction inherent in the minister's position. He has campaigned long and hard on the question of aviation safety and the lapses which have led to the Monarch and Seaview tragedies. But, on the other hand, his strongest support from within the industry and the closest agenda which he is associated with within the industry is that which is pushed by AOPA, which preaches affordable safety and less regulation. That inherent contradiction will come home to haunt the minister at some stage. The best example of this is his recent decision to override his own expert advice from CASA with respect to electronic located transmitters.

I will not go into the details of the decision, but it is a complex issue. The minister has chosen to allow hand-held ELTs to be used as substitutes for fixed ELTs. Neither of them totally cover each other. They are not interchangeable. I hope, for the minister's sake, that no situation arises in the future where a crash occurs in a remote area and people die because they did not have fixed transmitters and the hand-held transmitters were not appropriate in the circumstances. I hope, for his sake, that that is not the case.

This raises the question as to why the minister needs the review in the first place. He has already determined that he can override, unilaterally, the advice of his own safety regulator on what the content of regulation should be on this fairly important matter. Why doesn't he just do it for everything? If he is confident that he has the expertise and the knowledge to do so on this very complex issue of ELTs, why doesn't he simply do that on every other matter as well?

In conclusion, the issue of aviation safety regulation is far too important to be left purely to sectional interests within the industry. It is far too important to be the subject of ministerial whim with respect to individual regulations like the ELT regulation. It is far too important to be the subject of paybacks for previous political support.

The opposition supports the review of regulations that the minister has announced, as I said, subject to being informed of the detail of precisely who will conduct the inquiry and in what way it will be dealt with. The opposition calls on the minister to take off the cowboy boots and start dealing with aviation safety issues constructively, to not look for shoot-outs with the CASA board, to not overrule his own safety experts and to not appoint partisan advocates of sectional interests in the industry to the CASA board. The role of the board should essentially be that of an umpire; it is not there to be a battleground for sectional interests within the aviation industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) for the speeches he gave yesterday and tonight. According to the Queensland Department of Primary Industries' agribusiness marketing analyst, Mr Robert Doolan, the development of the food store retailing industry is occurring at a rapid pace across all Asian countries. BREAK.PARA: The other main trend which is occurring is the development of food service industries in Asian markets. This industry, Mr Doolan says, is the fastest growing industry in the Asian agribusiness system today. The growth in food service, which is essentially all food prepared away from home—for example, restaurants, fast food outlets, catering, hotels, hospitals, schools, the military and so on—has risen out of a number of common demographic trends. Increasing disposable income in Asia, busier lifestyles, an increasing number of working women and more single parent families mean less time to shop and prepare food. Therefore, it is easier to eat out or take away, and demand inevitably dictates supply. Australia should be focused on this opportunity for export.

In Japan, for example, 45 per cent of food is prepared away from home. The other 55 per cent is bought at retail outlets and prepared at home. This trend to increasingly eat out is being mirrored in other Asian countries as consumers become more pressed for time and demand greater convenience products.

Demand for convenient food inevitably means greater demand for convenience food such as microwaveable products and frozen foods, says Agribusiness Marketing Services. Australia has an advantage in its proximity to the Asian markets, so we can supply fresh food produce quickly.

I would like to quickly touch on two points relating to the bill. This represents almost 96 per cent of all enterprises. They generate almost a third of the country's gross domestic product. They are responsible for nearly half of total employment in Australia, which translates to about 3.6 million jobs. Small business is also playing a prominent role in research and development. For example, in 1993-94 the small business sector spent almost half a billion dollars on research and development. This represented 15 per cent of the total amount spent on R&D in Australia by all business enterprises. Secondly, I would like to refer to schedule 9 of the amendment bill. It establishes a grants entry test for first‐time export market development grants claimants. While the grants entry test will not be overly onerous, it will be there to provide that checking element. We have consistently heard of the need to pay attention to our Asia-Pacific neighbours. Asian markets and businesses, particularly in the retail food industries, are rapidly catching up in being able to provide quality products. It is no surprise that the reaction of small business has been one of shock, dismay and despair. The reason for that is that the export market development grants scheme actually benefits small businesses. It helps them to operate successfully, to grow and to become more prosperous. It is government and business working hand in hand to create jobs and wealth for this country.

Reviews of the scheme carried out in recent years have confirmed this. The main clients of the scheme are small to medium sized businesses. Yesterday's mail here at Parliament House contained a copy of the Australian Information Industry Association Bulletin representing the views of close to 85 per cent of the information technology and telecommunications industry. This is an industry with a large representation—around 70 per cent—of small and medium sized businesses, at the cutting edge of new technology and whose growth and prosperity is crucial to the wellbeing of this country. As that organisation said:

The chief benefit of the export market development grants scheme, as far as our membership is concerned, is that it is a benefit mostly available to small to medium enterprises. Further, in the information technology and telecommunications industry, that is particularly significant because there is a very high proportion of members who actually export.
How have the Australian Information Industry Association reacted to the possibility of the scheme being axed? In their bulletin they say:
EMDG is perhaps the only benefit at the present moment that is available to assist small and medium enterprises to export.
Over the page they say further:
What we are arguing against specifically now is the outright abolition of this scheme.
A little further on they say:
We would be fundamentally opposed to the abolition of the scheme.

I would like to talk briefly about the possible effects of the abolition of the scheme on a couple of local businesses. In Greensborough in the northern part of my electorate of Jagajaga is located Mi‐Sporting Products, better known, I am sure, to many football supporters in this House as Blades—the manufacturers and exporters of the world famous Blades sporting footwear. Through the sheer quality of its products, coupled with incredible tenacity in the face of adversity and ferocious competition, Blades has carved out a market for itself in the very competitive world sporting footwear market. Blades products are exported to the United Kingdom, South Africa, Sweden, Greece, Italy, Holland, Spain and a number of South American countries. Subcontract work for Blades forms the core business for 14 local companies.

Most people will remember the battle Blades had to establish their football boots with the then Victorian Football League. League marketing agreements gave exclusivity to other football companies, but VFL footballers generally preferred Blades. In a case that created a massive media carry‐on at the time, Essendon captain Simon Madden even went to the extent of painting white stripes on the sides of his Blades boots to try to circumvent his club's exclusivity arrangements. Today many AFL players wear Blades boots, including the whole of the Footscray football club. The boots are claimed to reduce the chances of knee injury, and in a year marked by a shocking incidence of knee injuries to AFL players none of the players injured were wearing Blades.

Blades is a wholly Australian owned company and describes itself as a company whose main business today consists of `research and development of new technology and the worldwide licensing and export of that technology'. In a letter to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade, the owner of Blades said:

We wish to protest in the strongest possible terms against the proposal to abolish the export market development grants scheme, as reported in the Australian Financial Review of Friday, 19 April 1996. We have put 11 years of research into the successful development of a revolutionary new technology for sporting shoes. This technology is used in the production of the Blades' range of sporting shoes now widely acknowledged as the world leaders for performance characteristics in their categories. The products have been well and truly tested and proved in the Australian and international markets, with extensive and growing sales, both here and overseas, particularly in the United Kingdom.

In order to fully exploit this Australian technology and to maintain our R&D program, we need to expand sales into the United States of America, Europe and Asia. These extremely competitive markets are driven by advertising and are dominated by the multinational household names such as Nike, Adidas, Reebok and Puma. They each spend literally millions of dollars annually on advertising and promotion. This sort of spending is far beyond our resources at present so, over the last 12 months, we have developed a responsible and cost‐effective export development strategy which will enable us to compete with these foreign companies.
A little later, the letter states:
The economic viability of the program depends on continuation of the EMDG scheme.
The letter also states—and I think this is the most important part of my remarks on this letter from the managing director of Blades—
Abolition of the EMDG scheme would mean, for us, the following things:

1. The loss of this window of opportunity to obtain for Australia a share of the multi‐billion dollar sports and leisure industry, with its potential spin‐off benefits for other Australian businesses, as well as increased employment opportunities.
2. Abandoning commitments to foreign firms, international agencies and world‐wide media organisations, with resulting damage to Australia's international trading reputation.
3. The damaging publicity caused by foreign and Australian media coverage of the chain of events.
4. Lost opportunities to enhance Australia's reputation as a leader in technological research and development.
5. Loss of valuable foreign currency and export incomes for Australia.
6. Curtailment of our extensive technological research and development program.
7. Possible staff reductions.
He finishes his letter by saying:
For these reasons, we strongly urge you to resist the proposal to abandon the EMDG scheme.

My colleague and neighbour, the member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), will also be referring to Blades, many of whose work force live in his electorate. He will also refer to the disgraceful treatment that this company is receiving from the Deputy Prime Minister. It is clear that this is a vital and innovative Australian company, competing in the world's toughest markets, whose future prospects are being placed in jeopardy by this government.

Another relatively young Melbourne company whose success and growth can, in great part, be attributed to the support of the export market development grants scheme is Shock Records. Shock Records started business in 1988, with a staff of three: the original owners and directors of the company. Today, Shock has a staff of 110 people and an annual turnover of $27 million.

The key point here is that, of that $27 million turnover, approximately $10 million comes from exporting—the exporting of Australian music and Australian manufactured music products. Further, the major part of that export growth occurred over the last five years—years when Shock Records was in receipt of assistance through the export market development grants scheme. In those five years, Shock's export division grew from one part‐time worker to around 20 full‐time employees.

According to Frank Falvo, the managing director of Shock exports, the EMDG scheme has assisted greatly in helping Shock to have the confidence to invest more strongly in export oriented activity. This encouragement occurred in two ways. Firstly, it encouraged Shock to offer more recording contracts to young Australian bands. Secondly, it further encouraged the company to commit large sums of money to the development and promotion of these bands, including financing tours to overseas markets.

As a result of these initiatives, Shock has signed numerous licensing arrangements with record companies in other countries, to release the recordings made by these artists. The Melbourne band Bodyjar is just one example of a band whose recordings have been licensed and successfully released into most of the world's music markets. Another is the Pearly Gatecrashers—I hasten to state that I have not heard of these bands myself, in case I sound too modern to those opposite—

TALK.START.PARA: —We know you are modern!
—My children certainly do not think I am. The Pearly Gatecrashers are about to release their second album in Japan. Shock, in fact, represents or distributes for export over 200 Australian bands.

SPEECH.PARA: That Shock is a company at the cutting edge of innovation in the music industry is even recognised by this government, I am pleased to say—it was in Hansard. Last week, in answer to a question about the price of compact discs, the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith) commented that Shock had introduced a major discounting campaign which, as he said, the government welcomed and the minister saw as reducing the need to consider abolishing copyright to allow parallel importing.

I suggest that that minister convey to his colleagues the views of Frank Falvo on the importance of the retention of the export market development grants scheme, EMDGS, in the ongoing success of the company. Mr Falvo states that the EMDG scheme allowed Shock Records the flexibility and backup support necessary to take investment risks with Australian bands.

In Falvo's view, the music industry faces two major threats to its continued viability. The first threat is the possible introduction of parallel importing and the second is the abolition of the export market development grants scheme. The proposal to end this scheme represents economic rationalism of the worst sort. There are still many opposite who have sold their souls to the concept of the level playing field, even if levelling the playing field involves cutting down our local champions, the likes of Blades and Shock Records.

Blades and Shock Records expanded their employment massively, as I have just demonstrated. It is not about picking winners; it is about helping those who have demonstrated their capacity to be winners to actually get out there and win.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mrs DE‐ANNE KELLY

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill. This is commonsense legislation to better target government assistance through the export market development grants scheme. I would like to give a brief overview of how the scheme works, the relevance of the EMDG scheme to the tourism industry—which I am proud to have a good deal of in my electorate—and, lastly, some of the amendments that are going to be made to the act through this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Export market development grants encourage Australian exporters to develop overseas markets for goods, services, industrial property rights and general know‐how. There is a 50 per cent reimbursement for the costs incurred in overseas marketing. I might add that, for the tourism industry at present, that reimbursement is only 25 per cent.

Prior to this legislation being enacted, the taxable grants have a maximum ceiling of $250,000. An individual or a company can have up to eight grants, with three additional grants for each new market that is opened. The definition of a `new market' is one where the export sales for the last three years are not greater than $300,000. There is also a $30,000 threshold. In other words, an individual or a company must have expenditure of $30,000 or more to be able to access the EMDG.
There are some sensible savings in better targeting this grant to assist fledgling exporters in small companies. In the mighty seat of Dawson—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well represented.

—Thank you. In the mighty seat of Dawson, where we have the Whitsundays, there is a great deal of use made of export market development grants by the tourism industry. I would like to give you one instance. We have an agricultural tour company and they assist visitors to come to Australia who are interested in our agricultural pursuits. For instance, overseas cattlemen visit Australia to have a look at the breeding herds here, to look at pasture development and so on. Next year there is to be held in Australia an international conference on beef breeding. This particular tourism company has had the foresight to distribute to 2,500 overseas beef breeders $40 packs describing the conditions in Australia, the herds, places to visit, pasture improvement and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a considerable expenditure, I must say, and they are able to do this because of the export market development grants scheme. Those who come to Australia plainly will increase the number who visit Australia and will also extend the time that they spend here and, hopefully, will extend the amount of money that they spend here as well. There is a considerable advantage for small exporters, which this agricultural tour company is, in having access to export market development grants.

I would just like to quote Keith Neilsen, who addressed our government committee on tourism last week. He is the Executive Director of the Association of Marine Park Tourism Operators. He has said that tourism is a big industry; it earns big dollars—they are disposable dollars. But people have to be convinced to take a holiday.

Tourism has done Australia very well in international terms. A few years ago, we had only one million visitors per year. Let me say that, of those one million visitors, 350,000 were repeat visitors and 650,000 were first‐time visitors. They have to be encouraged to come to Australia to spend their holiday. We are now up to the level of three million visitors per year, and what that means is that we have to attract as first‐time visitors 1.7 million visitors.

It is a considerable challenge for the tourism industry here, and I must say that it is a very expensive challenge. They have to convince the wholesalers and agents in other countries that Australia is the place to visit. The tourism industry has a very proud record as one of those who access export market development grants. Austrade has recorded that in 1993 the dollar export earnings compared to the dollar cost of grants for the tourism industry are in a ratio of 25 to one. In other words, for every dollar spent on the grant, Australia benefits by $25 in income, whereas manufacturing has a ratio of only 18 to one. Tourism makes good use of the grant. They convert those grant dollars into big export dollars for this country.

But there are other difficulties for the tourism industry. For example, if you are in manufacturing, it is very easy to put a spanner or a set of drawings into a post bag and send it overseas. Unfortunately, you cannot parcel up the Whitsundays and send them overseas—thank goodness! What we need is the opportunity to bring the wholesalers and agents to this country and have that recognised as a sample. They are the ones who will promote our product to potential customers overseas and they have to have a sample of Australia. The only way to sample a tourism destination is to go there and see all of the benefits that it offers.

I believe the tourism grant should in fact be 50 per cent. Our mighty tourism industry should be recognised as the great exporter that it is. I believe it should not take second place to other exporting industries and I look forward in the budget in August to tourism being recognised as a full grant recipient of the export market development grants scheme. I certainly trust that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) will keep to his commitment to see that tourism is recognised as a full export industry.

I now turn to some of the changes that this legislation will bring about. We will reduce the maximum grant from a quarter of a million dollars to $200,000. Only 200 claims made every year actually receive such a large grant—only five per cent of the overall claimants. These are the larger resource companies, companies that are well able to afford to promote their own activities overseas. We want to see grants directed at the small, emerging tourism and exporting sector.

BREAK.PARA: Another change will ensure that those claimants for an export market development grant will not be able to add to the expenditure after the claim has been submitted. There will be an allowance of 10 per cent of the overall expenditure to cover genuine reasons why amounts which have been overlooked should be expended. This will ensure that claims are completed on time and that the accounting is done thoroughly.

We will also limit the membership of multiple joint ventures and consortia. With the present threshold of $30,000, individuals and companies can join a consortium or a joint venture to access that threshold. We will limit to three the number of joint ventures that one can be a member of, although that will be varied at the minister's discretion should the need arise. This will prevent smaller export companies from overextending themselves and ultimately, perhaps, failing in their export drive.

We will also ensure that claims will be disallowed if they are prepared by a disqualified individual. Many of the exporters use consultants. Those who have been disqualified, on good grounds, will no longer be allowed to prepare claims. But all of those small businesses and exporters who have, with the best will, gone to a consultant will have a further 90 days to put in a fresh claim.

I am particularly pleased about the amendment whereby expenditure relating to illegal activities will not attract a grant. Australians would be, frankly, offended if taxpayer moneys were expended on what they saw as illegal activities, either in this country or in another country.

We will also prevent grant eligibility for an interposed company where somebody who was ordinarily employed by that company is, in fact, receiving a grant to cover wages or salaries. This practice has been used in some cases and the grant has been paid for ordinarily employed persons.

We will also bring in a register of first‐time claimants and a grants entry testing which will apply to about 1,200 new claimants every year who are trying to access the scheme. The registration will be very simple and it will look at five particular areas: importantly, whether the claimant has a product or a service for export; whether they are adequately resourced; whether they have done their market research; and whether their management has a commitment to an export drive. These are very commonsense changes that will better direct the grants to small and medium firms that are emerging as exporters.

I would now like to move on to a general discussion of the worth of savings. Certainly there are going to be savings from the amendments that are being made to the export market development grants scheme. This is most important. With the $8 billion black hole that we have, savings have to be found. It is necessary that we look at ways in which this can be done which still allow us to boost export earnings for this country, that still allow us to direct our activities towards the productive sector. It has to be done.

In view of the flak that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) is receiving as a result of the measures he is taking, I would like to make a comment now about our future Australians. During my maiden speech I mentioned that a nation is not simply those who live now; it is past Australians, it is present Australians and it is future Australians. I am very pleased to see that the government and the Treasurer are taking measures which are going to give our future Australians—our children and grandchildren—an opportunity that we in this country have enjoyed.

At the moment I believe that the previous government has mortgaged our children's future, that they have ransacked the future to pay for the present, that they have indulged in inter‐generational theft. I believe it is most important that our government takes a responsible view of the future, that while we care for the vulnerable and give a stimulus to the productive sector we ensure that we do not add to what has been a disgraceful record of inter‐generational debt.

I commend the Export Markets Development Grants Amendment Bill to the House. I look forward to future changes to the tourism industry which will put it on a similar footing to other export industries in this country in respect of the level of grant allowed.
